coredata.dc:description: Water electrolysis has been proven as an effective means to produce clean hydrogen energy, and such a process can be accelerated by active bifunctional electrocatalysts for both hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER). Herein, we adopted a laser ablation technique to prepare a strawberry-like catalyst with Co3O4 clusters embedded in Ag nanoparticles, realizing the ingenious mutual regulation of Co3O4 and Ag. The Co3O4 facilitates the water dissociation and optimizes the hydrogen adsorption of Ag by introducing tensile strain and low coordination number, resulting in a low HER overpotential of 51 mV at 10 mA cm−2. Meanwhile, the electron transfer from Co3O4 to Ag facilitates the oxidization of Co3O4 and improves the OER performance, leading to a low OER overpotential of 206 mV at 10 mA cm−2. Ultimately, an ultralow potential of 1.49 V for overall water splitting has been achieved at 10 mA cm−2, outperforming Pt/C+RuO2 couple.

xocs:item-toc-entry.xocs:item-toc-section-title: Synthesis of SLC, hybrid and heterostructure nanoparticles by laser ablation
Electronic structure of Ag and its influence on HER performance
Electronic structure of Co3O4 and its influence on OER performance

The authors acknowledge BL08U1A and BL14W1 beamlines of the Shanghai Synchrotron Radiation Facility (SSRF) for synchrotron beam time and Y. L. Liang from Shanghai Institute of Applied Physics (Chinese Academy of Sciences) for XAS measurements.

Liang from Shanghai Institute of Applied Physics ( Chinese Academy of Sciences ) for XAS measurements.

ce:caption.ce:simple-para: High-angle-annular-dark-filed scanning transmission electron microscope (HAADF-STEM) and energy disperse spectroscopy (EDS) mapping characterizations of SLC, hybrid and heterostructure nanoparticles. a) SLC, b) hybrid, c) heterostructure.

(a–c) The particle size distribution of a) SLC, b) hybrid and c) heterostructure. The insets are the schematic illustrations of SLC, hybrid and heterostructure, respectively. d-f) XRD patterns of d) SLC, e) hybrid and f) heterostructure. The horizontal arrows show broaden of Ag diffraction peak, and the up arrows show strengthen of Co3O4 diffraction peak. g-i) Raman spectra of g) SLC, h) hybrid and i) heterostructure influenced by SERS effect of Ag.

HER performance of SLC, hybrid, heterostructure and commercial Pt/C in 1 M KOH. a) HER polarization curves of SLC, hybrid, heterostructure and commercial Pt/C with a scan rate of 5 mV s−1 in Ar-saturated KOH aqueous solution, without iR compensation. b) Overpotentials of SLC, hybrid, heterostructure and commercial Pt/C at 10 mA cm−2 and 50 mA cm−2. c) Tafel plots calculated from (a). d) EIS spectra of SLC, hybrid and heterostructure nanoparticles. e) Double-layer capacitance of SLC, hybrid and heterostructure nanoparticles. f) The continuous HER catalytic stability test of SLC at the current density of −10 mA cm−2 for 100 h and −50 mA cm−2 for 100 h.

OER performance of SLC, hybrid, heterostructure and commercial RuO2 in 1 M KOH. a) OER polarization curves of SLC, hybrid, heterostructure and commercial RuO2 with a scan rate of 5 mV s−1 in O2-saturated KOH aqueous solution, without iR compensation. b) Overpotentials of SLC, hybrid, heterostructure and commercial Pt/C at 10 mA cm−2 and 50 mA cm−2. c) Tafel plots calculated from (a). d) EIS spectra of SLC, hybrid and heterostructure nanoparticles. e) OER polarization curves before and after 2000-cycle CV. f) The continuous OER catalytic stability test of SLC at the current density of 10 mA cm−2 for 100 h and 50 mA cm−2 for 100 h.

XAS and DFT analysis of Ag for HER performance. a) Bulk normalized Ag K-edge XANES spectra of SLC, hybrid, heterostructure and reference Ag foil, Ag NPs. Inset, magnified pre-edge XANES region. b) Bulk normalized Fourier transformed (FT) k3-weighted χ (k)-function of the EXAFS spectra for SLC, hybrid, heterostructure and reference Ag foil, Ag NPs at Ag K-edge. c) The comparison of Ag coordination numbers value for SLC, hybrid, heterostructure, Ag foil and Ag NPs reference calculated by fitting EXAFS curve at Ag K-edge. d) The effect of different coordination numbers on hydrogen adsorption Gibbs free energy (ΔGH*) of Ag (111) surface. e) The effect of different tensile strains on ΔGH* of Ag (111) surface. f) Gibbs free energy diagram of water dissociation on Co3O4, Ag and Pt.

XAS and difference charge density analysis of Co3O4. a) Surface-sensitive TEY XAS scans at the Co L2, 3-edge of SLC, hybrid, heterostructure and reference CoO, Co2O3. b) Bulk normalized XANES spectra recorded at Co K-edge of SLC, hybrid, heterostructure and reference Co foil, Co3O4. Inset, magnified pre-edge XANES region. c) Bulk normalized Fourier transformed (FT) k3-weighted χ (k)-function of the EXAFS spectra for SLC, hybrid, heterostructure and reference Co foil, Co3O4 at Co K-edge. d) Charge density distribution of Ag/Co3O4 interface.

Evaluation of the overall water splitting performance of SLC and commercial Pt/C+RuO2. a) Polarization curves of SLC and commercial Pt/C+RuO2 for overall water splitting in 1 M KOH tested in a two-electrode electrochemical cell. b) Overpotentials of SLC and commercial Pt/C+RuO2 derived from overall water splitting polarization curves at current density of 10 and 50 mA cm−2, respectively. c) Comparison of overpotentials for SLC and other reported catalysts [34–46]. d) Current-time (i-t) chronoamperometric response and corresponding Faradaic efficiency (F.E.) of SLC catalyst held at the current densities of 50 mA cm−2 for 50 h in 1 M KOH. e) The volume ratio of H2/O2 produced by SLC catalyst held at current densities of 50 mA cm−2 for 50 h, inset is the schematic diagram of practical overall water splitting.

Schematic illustration on the synthesis and structure of SLC, hybrid and heterostructure nanoparticles by pulsed laser ablation in liquid. The diagrams on the right of scheme represent the cutaway view of SLC, hybrid and heterostructure.

head.ce:title: Strawberry-like Co3O4-Ag bifunctional catalyst for overall water splitting

ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: Institute of New Energy Materials, School of Materials Science and Engineering, Tianjin University, Tianjin 300072, PR China

sa:affiliation.sa:organization: Institute of New Energy Materials, School of Materials Science and Engineering, Tianjin University

ce:affiliation.ce:source-text: Institute of New Energy Materials, School of Materials Science and Engineering, Tianjin University, Tianjin 300072, PR China

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Water electrolysis has been proven as an effective means to produce clean hydrogen energy, and such a process can be accelerated by active bifunctional electrocatalysts for both hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER). Herein, we adopted a laser ablation technique to prepare a strawberry-like catalyst with Co3O4 clusters embedded in Ag nanoparticles, realizing the ingenious mutual regulation of Co3O4 and Ag. The Co3O4 facilitates the water dissociation and optimizes the hydrogen adsorption of Ag by introducing tensile strain and low coordination number, resulting in a low HER overpotential of 51 mV at 10 mA cm−2. Meanwhile, the electron transfer from Co3O4 to Ag facilitates the oxidization of Co3O4 and improves the OER performance, leading to a low OER overpotential of 206 mV at 10 mA cm−2. Ultimately, an ultralow potential of 1.49 V for overall water splitting has been achieved at 10 mA cm−2, outperforming Pt/C+RuO2 couple.

Utilizing the non-equilibrium synthesis method of the laser ablation, this work investigates a unique strawberry-like Co3O4-Ag composite with Co3O4 clusters embedding in Ag substrate. Through the ingenious mutual regulation and synergic effect of the two components, the catalytic activity of the inactive component can be improved simultaneously, thereby achieving outstanding overall water splitting performance.

ce:section.ce:para: Water electrolysis has been recognized as an efficient way to produce clean hydrogen energy by utilizing surplus electricity, thus reducing the consumption of fossil fuels and easing the global warming issue [1,2]. Water electrolysis consists of two half-reactions: hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER), in which high-activity catalysts play a critical role [3]. In particular, excellent bifunctional catalysts for both HER and OER are highly anticipated because they can simplify the processes for fabricating catalysts and assembling devices [4–6].

Recently, many bifunctional catalysts have been exploited for overall water splitting, and most of them are composed of noble metals (Pt, Ir, Ru, etc) and transition metal compounds (such as metal oxides, sulfides, nitrides, and phosphides) [7–10]. Various techniques have been adopted to promote the catalytic activity, including alloying, introducing defects, constructing core-shell structure, etc [11–14]. For instance, Lin et al. developed a Ru-doped NiFeP catalyst for water electrolysis by optimizing the electronic structure [13]; Li et al. build up PdCu/Ir core-shell nanocrystals to promote overall water splitting by inducing exclusive strain [14]. Although these noble-metal-based catalysts exhibit excellent properties, their high price limits the wide application [15,16]. Therefore, developing cheap and efficient HER and OER bifunctional catalysts becomes an urgent issue.

An active HER catalyst should possess optimum hydrogen adsorption ability. Among various metallic catalysts, silver is the most earth-abundant, cheapest, and most conductive noble metal. Nevertheless, due to the fully filled d band structure, sliver exhibits very weak hydrogen adsorption capacity and poor HER performance [17]. Recently, we employed a laser ablation process to prepare silver nanoparticles with abundant stacking faults, and turned the inactive silver into an effective HER catalyst comparable to noble metal Pt [18]. In contrast, an effective OER catalyst should adsorb hydroxyl and oxygen intermediates appropriately. Cobalt oxide (Co3O4) with low cost has been used for OER [19–21], while its intrinsic catalytic activity is barely satisfactory [20,22]. In recent work, we also adopted laser ablation to generate abundant oxygen vacancies in Co3O4, as such, the electronic structure and catalytic performance were remarkably improved [23,24].

Since laser ablation can improve the HER properties of Ag and OER properties of Co3O4, we then conceive of preparing a Co3O4-Ag composite catalyst by laser ablation so as to obtain a bifunctional catalyst for water electrolysis. More importantly, the electron transfer between the two components may optimize their electronic structure, further enhancing both HER and OER performance [25–28]. Besides, it was found that Co3O4 could promote water dissociation, thus facilitating the alkaline HER activity of the composite structure [19,29,30].

Herein, we synthesized a Co3O4-Ag strawberry-like catalyst (SLC) by laser ablation of a bimetal AgCo target immersed in water. The Ag substrate with embedded Co3O4 clusters exhibits low coordination numbers and high tensile strain which jointly improve the hydrogen adsorption. Combined with the excellent water dissociation ability of Co3O4, SLC presents an excellent alkaline HER activity which superior to commercial Pt/C. Meanwhile, the electron transfer between the two components improves the OER activity of Co3O4 to a level higher than commercial RuO2. As a bifunctional catalyst for water electrolysis, SLC outperforms the noble-metal couple (Pt/C+RuO2) and most of the state-of-the-art bifunctional catalysts.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Synthesis of SLC, hybrid and heterostructure nanoparticles by laser ablation
ce:section.ce:para: The SLC nanoparticles were prepared using a nanosecond pulsed laser (Nd: YAG, Nimma-600). An AgCo target (99.99%, AgCo = 1.5:1) with a diameter of 20 mm and a thickness of 5 mm, was ablated by a focused beam for 30 min. The laser energy was 200 mJ with a wavelength of 1064 nm and a frequency of 15 Hz. The target was immersed in deionized water, and the upper surface of the target was 20 mm from the water surface. Then the obtained colloidal solution of SLC nanoparticles was concentrated by high-speed centrifugation (18,000 rpm, 10 min, SIGMA-3K30), and dried by a vacuum freeze dryer (Biocool-FD-1–50).

The hybrid and heterostructure nanoparticles were synthesized by the same laser ablation method described above, except for the difference in laser beam energy. The hybrid nanoparticles were prepared with the laser energy of 400 mJ, and the heterostructure nanoparticles were prepared with the laser energy of 500 mJ.

The microstructure and morphology of the catalysts were observed by a JEOL 2100 F transmission electron microscope (TEM, 200 kV). The crystal structure was analyzed through a Bruker D8 Advanced X-ray diffraction (XRD) with the Cu Kα radiation source. The Raman spectrum was obtained on a RENISHAW inVia reflectance Raman spectrometer (spectral resolution: <1 cm−1). The element ratios of the catalysts were tested by inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS, Agilent 7700x).

The XAS measurements were conducted at Shanghai Synchrotron Radiation Facility (SSRF). The surface soft XAS measurement was carried out on the BL08U1A beamline, where the photon energy is optimized between 250 eV and 2000 eV (ΔE/E, 10,000@244 eV, 7400@410 eV). The bulk hard XAS test was performed on the BL14W1 beamline, where transmission mode was used to collect X-ray absorption fine structure (XAFS). Then the XAFS data was processed by Athena and Artemis software.

The HER and OER catalytic activity were measured using a CHI660E electrochemical workstation in Ar (HER) / O2 (OER)-saturated 1.0 M KOH electrolytes (reference electrode: KCl-saturated Hg/Hg2Cl2 electrode, counter electrode: graphite rod). The working electrode is an electrocatalyst-loaded glassy carbon electrode (GCE, 0.07 cm2, 0.4 mg cm−2). Specifically, 4 mg catalyst powders and 6 mg carbon black were mixed in 500 μl isopropanol, 500 μl deionized water and 20 μl Nafion solution (5 wt%, Du Pont) to form the catalyst ink, which was then spread on the GCE. Before the electrochemical tests, 50 cycles of cyclic voltammetry (CV) at a scan rate of 50 mV s−1 were performed to stabilize the catalyst, then the linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) curves were recorded at a scan rate of 5 mV s−1.

The overall water splitting measurements were carried out by using a two-electrode system in 1 M KOH. The synthesized catalyst was loaded onto the surface of Teﬂon-treated carbon fiber paper (CFP) as both anode and cathode (1 cm × 3 cm, 1 mg cm−2). As a control, commercial Pt/C and RuO2 with a mass ratio of 1:1 were also tested on the CFP (1 cm × 3 cm, 1 mg cm−2). For the measurement of gas product during the overall water splitting, a gastight H-type cell was employed to collect the gas produced by cathode and anode separately. The Faradaic efficiency (F.E.) of H2 was detected and calculated by gas chromatography (GC, online test, Agilent-7890B). The ratio of H2 and O2 produced in the different cells was tested by drainage, from which the gas efficiency can be estimated.

The DFT computation was conducted through Ab initio Simulation Package (cutoff energy of the plane waves basis: 500 eV; Monkhorst-Pack mesh in K-sampling: 3 × 3 × 1; energy convergence tolerance: 10−5 eV/each atom; final force: < 0.01 eV Å−1/each atom). The Dimer method in the VTST package was used in transition state (TS) searches, with the convergence criterion for the electronic wavefunction of 10−6 eV. The initial guess geometries were formed by the climbing-image nudged elastic band (CI-NEB) method, following by the dimer method to converge to the saddle points.

The vacuum layer for all periodic slabs was at least 15 Å. In order to form the heterojunction of Ag and Co3O4, Ag (111) crystal plane and the Co3O4 (111) crystal plane were chosen, with the original crystal plane parameters of u=v= 5.88514 Å, γ = 120.0000˚ and u=v= 5.75470 Å, γ = 120.0000˚, respectively. The difference in cell length is about 2.3%, which meets the requirements for constructing a heterojunction. Ag and Co contact interface was used to building the heterojunction, and the crystal plane parameter after relaxation is u=v= 5.77809 Å, γ = 119.6470˚.

The adsorption energy of reaction intermediates can be computed by ΔG = ΔE + ΔZPE – TΔS (ΔZPE: zero-point energy change; ΔS: entropy change) ΔZPE and ΔS are obtained from the vibration frequency calculations. For the calculation of the deformation charge density, the heterojunction model after relaxation is used, according to ∆ρ = ρAg-Co3O4 −ρAg – ρCo3O4.

The Co3O4-Ag SLC was prepared facilely by laser ablation of a bimetal AgCo target immersed in deionized water. As shown in Scheme 1, the target was firstly heated into vapor and/or plasma state, and then the Co atoms were oxidized by the dissolved oxygen in water. Simultaneously, the high-temperature species were quenched by the cool water to a solid-state, leading to Co3O4-Ag composite nanoparticles. Intriguingly, the morphology and composition of the product vary with the energy of the laser beam. SLC with Co3O4 clusters embedded in Ag substrate was obtained at a laser energy of 200 mJ, while Co3O4 nanoparticles grow on the surface of Ag nanoparticle at a laser energy of 500 mJ, forming a typical heterostructure. At moderate laser energy of 400 mJ, Co3O4 clusters present both in the internal and on the surface of Ag nanoparticles, forming a hybrid structure of SLC and heterostructure. ICP-MS shows a similar component ratio of the three samples (Ag/Co atomic ratio is about 3/2, Table S1).

Elemental distribution in SLC, heterostructure and hybrid structure was investigated by energy disperse spectroscopy (EDS) mapping. As shown in Fig. 1(a), Co3O4 distributes across the outer layer of the SLC nanoparticle, indicating that Co3O4 is inserted in the Ag substrate. For heterostructure nanoparticles (Fig. 1c), Co3O4 nanoparticles merely appear on the surface of Ag substrate; while in hybrid nanoparticles, Co3O4 exists both in the internal and on the surface of Ag substrate (Fig. 1b). The high-resolution transmission electron microscope (HRTEM) images confirm the different distribution of Co3O4 in the three structures (Fig. S1–S3). Meanwhile, the particle sizes of the product gradually decrease in the order of SLC, hybrid and heterostructure ( Fig. 2a–c, S4–S6), reflecting the gradual separation of the embedded clusters to the surface. In the XRD pattern of SLC (Fig. 2d), the Ag-related peaks broaden due to the reduced crystal size of Ag substrate caused by the insertion of fine Co3O4 clusters, accompanied by the weakening of Co3O4-related peaks. On the contrary, Co3O4 diffraction peak intensity is enhanced in hybrid and heterostructure particles (Fig. 2e, f and S7). In Raman measurement, Co3O4 will show enhancement peaks due to the surface-enhanced Raman scattering (SERS) of Ag in the composite structure (Fig. S8) [31,32]. And the more contact interface between Ag and Co3O4, the stronger Raman enhancement effect of Co3O4. The SERS peaks increase by the order of heterostructure, hybrid and SLC because of the gradual rising of the interface between Ag and Co3O4 (Fig. 2g–i). The above results confirmed the different configurations of the three composite catalysts and more closely contacting Ag/Co3O4 interfaces in SLC.

The water electrolysis performance of the composite catalysts were tested in 1 M KOH using a reversible hydrogen electrode calibration (RHE, Fig. S9), without insulation resistance (iR) compensation. For HER activity ( Fig. 3a–c), SLC presents the optimized HER performance in the four samples (SLC, hybrid, heterostructure and Pt/C) (Fig. 3a), with the lowest overpotential (51 mV at 10 mA cm−2 and 113 mV at 50 mA cm−2, Fig. 3b) and Tafel slope (49 mV dec−1, Fig. 3c), which outperforms commercial Ag and Co3O4 nanoparticles and the state-of-the-art HER catalysts (Fig. S10 and Table S2). Besides, electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) measurement displays the depressed charge transfer resistance by the order of heterostructure, hybrid and SLC (Fig. 3d). Electrochemical active surface area (ECSA) tested by double-layer capacitance shows the increased number of active sites of SLC (Fig. 3e and Fig. S11). All of these results suggest the high HER activity of SLC. Moreover, SLC also exhibits excellent HER performance in 0.1 M KOH electrolyte (Fig. S12). After 200 h of continuous i-t testing at the potentials of −10 mA cm−2 and −50 mA cm−2, there is no significant decrease in current density (Fig. 3f), indicating a long-term HER durability of SLC.

As for OER activity ( Fig. 4a–c), SLC also presents the best OER activity among the four samples (SLC, hybrid, heterostructure and RuO2) (Fig. 4a), with the lowest overpotential (206 mV at 10 mA cm−2 and 274 mV at 50 mA cm−2, Fig. 4b) and Tafel slope (55 mV dec−1, Fig. 4c), which are superior to commercial Ag and Co3O4 nanoparticles and most of the state-of-the-art OER catalysts (Fig. S13 and Table S3). At the same time, EIS measurement displays a lowest charge transfer resistance for SLC (Fig. 4d), which jointly suggest the high OER activity. Meanwhile, SLC also exhibits excellent OER performance in 0.1 M KOH electrolyte (Fig. S14). SLC shows good cycle stability after 2000-cycle of CV measurement, of which the polarization curve displays no obvious shift (Fig. 4e). And after 100 h of continuous i-t testing at the potentials of 10 mA cm−2 and 50 mA cm−2, there is no significant decrease in current density (Fig. 4f), indicating a long-term OER durability of SLC.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Electronic structure of Ag and its influence on HER performance
ce:section.ce:para: Synchrotron-based XAS measurements were performed to analyze the coordination environment of Ag substrate for SLC, hybrid and heterostructure. Ag K-edge X-ray absorption near-edge structure spectroscopy (XANES) shows that the absorption edges of the three samples are almost overlapped, which reveals that Ag substrate keeps the metallic state in SLC, hybrid and heterostructure ( Fig. 5a and S15). Normalized Fourier transformed (FT) k3 χ (k) functions of extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) data in R-space indicate that the average Ag-Ag bond lengths of SLC, hybrid are 2.70 Å and 2.63 Å, respectively, which are longer than those of heterostructure (2.60 Å) and Ag foil (2.60 Å) (Fig. 5b). The elongation of Ag–Ag bond length indicates the tensile strain is present in SLC and hybrid structures, and the strain extent increases with the amount of embedded Co3O4 clusters. Moreover, the Ag–Ag bond intensity decreases with the embedded Co3O4, reflecting the decline of coordination number (Fig. 5b, S16). The average coordination number value could be calculated by fitting the first Ag-Ag shell EXAFS data in R-space (Fig. 5c, S17 and S18), from which we can find that the coordination number decrease in the order of heterostructure (~8.9), hybrid (~7.1) and SLC (~5.8). Obviously, the coordination number reduction originates from the embedding of Co3O4. Therefore, the embedding of Co3O4 could introduce tensile strain and reduce coordination number of Ag substrate.

To further prove the influence of embedded Co3O4 on Ag substrate, we removed the embedded Co3O4 clusters in SLC by acid etching. As shown in HAADF-STEM and EDS mapping images (Fig. S19), Co3O4 component disappears and the particle size of SLC decreases after chemical etching. Moreover, the XRD peaks became as narrow as those of Ag nanoparticles, indicating the growth of Ag grains (Fig. S20). EXAFS analysis reveals that the tensile strain in SLC disappears and the coordination number of SLC is similar to that of Ag nanoparticles with the same particle size (Fig. S21 and S22).

Subsequently, DFT calculations were performed to probe the influence of Ag electronic structure on HER performance. Firstly, we calculated hydrogen adsorption energy (ΔGH*). Based on the above XAS results, we constructed atomic models for SLC with different coordination numbers (Fig. S23) and different tension strains. As shown in Fig. S24, ΔGH* of bulk Ag is 0.54 eV, suggesting very weak hydrogen adsorption energy and poor HER activity (Fig. S25). While for SLC, ΔGH* values of Ag descend with the decrease in coordination number and increase in tensile strain, suggesting remarkable improvement of the hydrogen adsorption energy (Fig. 5d and e).

Apart from the hydrogen adsorption, water dissociation is another critical step for alkaline HER. From the kinetic viewpoint, the energy barrier for water dissociation on Ag (2.27 eV) is much higher than that on Pt (1.32 eV) (Fig. 5f, S26 and S27), which leads to a worse alkaline HER activity (Fig. S28). The calculated results indicate that the decrease in coordination number and the increase in tensile strain of Ag substrate have no obvious effect on water dissociation (Fig. S29). Different from the Ag, Co3O4 shows a very low energy barrier for water dissociation (1.02 eV, Fig. 5f and S30), which is even lower than that on Pt. Besides, Co3O4 possesses a high ΔGH* (0.62 eV), thus Co3O4 is poor for hydrogen adsorption (Fig. S31 and S32).

Based on the above, Co3O4 in SLC can promote water dissociation, while the Ag substrate facilitates hydrogen adsorption, and they jointly establish a typical metal/metal-oxide couple to catalyze alkaline HER [29,30]. The synergistic catalytic process was proven by control experiments. As shown in Fig. S33, the HER activity of SLC decays sharply after chemical etching. Moreover, the heterostructure catalyst also presents high HER activity (Fig. S34). The two results confirm the regulation effect of Co3O4 on Ag and the synergetic effect of Ag/Co3O4 heterojunction.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Electronic structure of Co3O4 and its influence on OER performance
ce:section.ce:para: XAS with total electron yield (TEY) intensity at Co L2,3 edges were adopted to probe the valence state of the Co ions. As seen in Fig. 6(a), the low energy peak (peak 1) and high energy peak (peak 2) are ascribed to Co2+ and Co3+ ions, respectively. The ratios of high/low-energy peaks increase gradually with the amount of embedding Co3O4 (SLC > hybrid > heterostructure), suggesting the increase in the valence state of Co ions. The XANES spectra also confirm the increase in Co oxidation state of SLC. As shown in Fig. 6(b), the absorption edge at Co K-edge shifts to the higher energy side by the order of heterostructure, hybrid and SLC. In addition, no peak change was found in O K-edge XAS spectra (Fig. S35), which illustrates the lattice oxygen has not changed. Besides, normalized Fourier transformed (FT) k3 χ (k) functions of EXAFS in R-space at Co K-edge disclose the information on the coordination environment of Co-Co and Co-O shells (Fig. 6c). The ratio of Co-O/Co-Co decreases with the embedding Co3O4 by the order of heterostructure, hybrid and SLC (Fig. S36). The decrease of Co-O/Co-Co combined with the increase of Co valence state jointly illustrate that electrons transfer from Co to Ag in SLC.

Next, we discuss the origin of the high OER activity of SLC. Firstly, pure Ag nanoparticles show a very poor OER performance (590 mV at 5 mA cm−2, Fig. S37), while pure Co3O4 nanoparticles exhibit a much better OER performance (Fig. S38), but the overpotential at 10 mA cm−2 is still very high (358 mV). As shown in Fig. S39, Co (III) ions in Co3O4 is widely accepted as the active site for OER, and Co (III) ions could be firstly oxidized into Co (IV) ions to catalyze following OER steps [33]. The calculation on the charge density distribution at Ag/Co3O4 interface reveals that the electrons could transfer from Co to Ag, leading to the valence rising of Co ions (Fig. 6d). The electron transfer between Ag and Co makes the oxidation and activation of Co (III) to Co (IV) more easily (Fig. S40), resulting in the high OER activity of SLC. The above results demonstrate the regulation effect of Ag on Co3O4.

Based on the high HER/OER bifunctional catalytic activity (Fig. S41), we then evaluate the potentials of SLC for overall water splitting. SLC catalyst was loaded on carbon fiber paper (CFP) and utilized directly as both anode and cathode for an electrolyzer. For comparison, RuO2 and Pt/C were adopted as anode and cathode catalysts, respectively. As shown in Fig. 7(a), SLC shows an overall water splitting performance higher than Pt/C + RuO2 couple. Specifically, SLC displayed operating potentials of ~1.49 and ~1.605 V for delivering current densities of 10 and 50 mA cm−2, respectively, which are much less than ~1.676 V @ 10 mA cm−2 and ~1.961 V @ 50 mA cm−2 of Pt/C + RuO2 couple (Fig. 7b). These values are also lower than those of other catalysts for overall water splitting (Fig. 7c and Table S4). Meanwhile, the SLC displayed an acceptable stability with negligible current density loss during 50 h continuous testing (Fig. 7d). Moreover, the faradaic efficiency and gas yield tests reveal the high energy conversion efficiency and stability of SLC for overall water splitting (~100%, Fig. 7d and e).

We prepared a strawberry-like metal-oxide/metal composite to improve the catalytic properties of inactive components as well as take the synergic effect of oxide/metal couple to promote water electrolysis. Experimental and theoretical results demonstrate that the embedded Co3O4 significantly improved the hydrogen adsorption energy of Ag substrate by changing its coordination number and tensile strain. Combining the excellent water dissociation ability of Co3O4 with the optimized hydrogen adsorption of Ag substrate, the strawberry-like metal-oxide/metal composite presents excellent alkaline HER activity. At the same time, the electron transfer from Co3O4 to Ag makes Co3O4 display high OER activity. We believe that this elegantly designed composite will open a new avenue for the development of highly active catalysts and the advancement of industrialization.

Yi Feng: Investigation, Formal analysis, Visualization, Writing – original draft. Zhe Li: Investigation, Formal analysis, Methodology, Supervision. Chuanqi Cheng: DFT analysis. Wenjing Kang: Investigation, Visualization. Jing Mao: Methodology. Gurong Shen: Methodology. Jing Yang: Methodology. Cunku Dong: Investigation, Methodology. Hui Liu: Investigation, Formal analysis. Xiwen Du: Writing – review & editing, Supervision, Project administration.
